transcript.content: Ron Wiggins Transcription REDACTIONS FINAL

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: My name Ron Wiggins, I'm arrested for second degree murder. I'm, you want to know where I'm from?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I want to know how old you are.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Oh, I was 23 and I'm 54 in December.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So you've served 31.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: 31 years, February 24th coming up.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Alright. Where are you from?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: New Orleans.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. I'm going to ask you some questions about growing up there. Maybe we can just start with, where did you grow up in New Orleans?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: In the uptown area, 3rd ward. New Orleans, Jackson Street.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Jackson and what?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Clara.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So I know it's been awhile since you were in New Orleans. But, can you take us back there a little bit, maybe tell me a little bit about your childhood and the people who raised you?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: My grandmother, she raised me. I was born in New Orleans, I went to New York when I was a kid. We come from New York when I was 2 months old. My dad used to be a seaman. So wherever shipping was good, he and my mom used to go. So we was in New York staying with a lady, and my mom went to go to the ice box to feed us, the lady had a lock on the ice box.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: She called her mom, which is my grandmother. And my grandmother said send them back to New Orleans. So my grandmother and her mom, which is my great grandmother we stayed in New Orleans since I was 2 months old.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh wow. And your siblings?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: My son, my son.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: No, your siblings?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Oh my brothers and sisters?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, did them also.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Yeah, yeah. Me, my brother, my sister, my oldest cousin Mooney which, she is a retired school teacher. She raised us, without my mom or brother daughter. My grandmother raised her from 2 weeks old.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Wow. Is your grandmother still alive?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: She died in 1993 with cancer.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you remember your last interaction with her?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: On the phone, and I cried because I called her and she was just getting dementia. And as I talked to her, she was talking to me, she just went off. Like when I'm coming to get her, when I'm coming to bring her to church.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How old was she then?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: She come from Meridian, Mississippi in 1908 she was 12 years old. So she died in '93. So I guess she was 70 something or close to it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Were there any men in her life that came into contact with you?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: That's a good question because I asked Mooney that. I said did mom, we called her mom, I said did mom every have a man? Case I never saw my grandmother with a man, she lived for children. You know, she worked in laundry her whole life until the early 70s, till cancer. And she and her sister, stayed crossed the street, which is my grandmother's sister, they owned all the houses on both sides of the street. They bought them real cheap back then.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Were you, do you feel that you grew up in a loving, nurturing household with adults who cared for you?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I feel my grandmother, she was my mom and she was my dad. But I feel like life would've been different if my mom and my dad would have been there. But, I also understand that during them times people had to work. So I might have seen my dad every year one time. Because he was a seaman so he might be in Africa, Egypt, wherever, he used to ride ships out there.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: But, if somebody asked you if you were mistreated as child, what would you say?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: No, I was never mistreated as a child. Back then, kids wasn't getting, wasn't getting cell phones. We got skates from the hardware store. My grandmother made sure we had everything we needed.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What about school? Can you tell me about your school?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I went to Macdonald 36 elementary school. My grandmother took us out of there and sent us to 70 school.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, how old were you then?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: About, maybe 9.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What was the highest year of school that you completed?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: 12th.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you like school?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: No. And it was funny because my mom was a school teacher. My older sister was a school teacher. I had an aunt who was principal. No, I never really liked school. I used to go to Loyola after school to take classes.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What classes were you taking?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Dealing with reading.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Did you ever get kicked out of school?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Yeah, for fighting.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: For fighting, a lot?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: No.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay. I'm trying to get a sense of Clara, I know where you're talking about, Clara and Jackson...

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Right there, it's Claiborne and Jackson, then Willow, then Clara.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: That's right, so quite far up.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: When you come off the I-10, you're going to get to Martin Luther King now, then you're going to get to, then you're going to get to Jackson, when you're leaving here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, I know exactly where it is now. Did you have somebody, like a best friend growing up? Who did you get along best with when you look back?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: We had family. It was like family. I mean I had a few best friends, all of them dead now accept one.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How did they die?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: One of them got killed in 1989. One of them, he's on drugs. Another one, he's in California, he apprenticed.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Were drugs and alcohol part of your life?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: No.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, is it fair to say your life took a turn down the wrong road before this charge?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Yeah.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Can you tell me a bit about that?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I think environments play a big role on everything because, don't forget I told you, we stay on Jackson and Clara. You got the project here, you got the project there, you got the St. Thomas project there, and you got the Magnolia project there. In them days, people wasn't shooting and killing but if you went to the police station where they used to have a sandwich shop.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: If you go to the sandwich shop right there, the bad boys from out the projects they'll want to take your sandwich, take your leather coat. So, we were from like Jackson Street, so we had to prove that we was tough too. So, I think environments play a big role on everything.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Absolutely. Did you get in quite a few fights?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Yeah that's what everybody did, they'd fight, and nobody shoot. You had to prove, okay I'm not from out the projects but I'm the dude too, don't come on Jackson street with this.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. What about girls? Tell me a little about your relationships with girls.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Oh man, girls. I been married 3 times. Me and my childhood girlfriend, I mean, me and her was, she the first girl I ever encountered, at school. But after, the streets took my life, it separated us. I think it's in interacting with different cultures and different people.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. Do you have any children?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Yeah I have a son.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Tell me about him.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I have a son, he'll be 32 September 24, he's a banker at the bank. He graduated from Southeastern. He's a cool cat, he do all this, he's a banker, he deal with rappers, and he's been in People magazine dealing with rappers. He's an all-around guy, keep always trying to get his business or something going, established.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: He comes to see me. I can call him when I want, whatever I ask him for, he'll take care of. I feel like, I cheated him by not being in his life. His mom, she did the best she could do and he came out good because he got academic scholarships to go to Southeastern. He a real smart guy.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How old was he when you were incarcerated?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: 16 months.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What does he think about his dad?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I mean, it hurts him too. He always tells me he's always been looking every year until he turned 9, he was looking for me to always come home, and I never made it home. He have kids too, so he's very active in his kids' lives. He do everything, they do the soccer thing, and they go to Tulane for swimming classes. He's a better man than I can ever be.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I think it's interesting that you've maintained a relationship with him though. So, he obviously thinks that something is worth- it's worth something to him to have a relationship with you.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Well, his grandmother, his mom always let him know, it wasn't like I was abusive to him or his mom before prison became my, I always reached out, talked to him, just guide him right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. Do you remember the first time you got arrested?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: First time I got arrested, yeah. I was 12 years old. 11 or 12.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What happened?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I and a guy was together. And he walked out the store with a hat. And they arrested both of us. And he was an adult, he was the coach at the park that we used to go to.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What about after that. What other brushes with the law did you have?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Like I said, I went to jail for simple robbery, I was 16.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: In the parish?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: No, as a juvenile. City Youth center, maybe 2, 3, months. Robert Gladford was my attorney. My mom got me Robert Glads. Uptown isn't a real crime area, so it looked like every time something happened in the neighborhood I've been arrested for all kind of things. Only been convicted for this.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, what lead to that?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: What lead to this? Many altercations I was getting into with people.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I mean if you had to pinpoint one thing, one reason, that you ended up with this charge what would that be?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: People owing me money.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, sure. So, were you dealing drugs?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Yes I was dealing drugs.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Makes sense. But you said that drugs and alcohol wasn't part of your own life.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Even then everybody you might not get high but you might have another vice.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What was your vice?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Having.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. Heroin, did that have anything to do with the circumstances of your charge?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: No, I'm arrested for a killing in Jefferson parish, didn't have anything to do with it.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Okay, well.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I ain't say heroin, I mean having. You said what my vice was, I got addicted to having.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Oh, I'm sorry, having, you got addicted to having, I heard heroin for some reason. So one of the reasons that we wanted to talk with you and you were identified as somebody to talk with is because you're now considered a model inmate. A trusted member of the community who's turned his life around. How old were you when you were brought through the gates of Angola, do you remember that bus ride?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: 23. Can you describe that person?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Man, I mean. I was mad, angry because of the circumstances, how I get here. Turning myself in with my lawyer, he told me a bunch of things that wasn't did. I mean I was convicted for killing somebody without a witness, without a gun. I mean, you gone be mad- prison was totally different than it is now. Just a mad person when I got here, they working in the fields all day, crazy.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I mean I was just angry and mad. Because I'm like man I turned myself in for this, lawyer sold me out, yeah. I was just a mad person, I mean, and through being mad you make bad decisions, even when you get in prison.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What were your days like when you first came here?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Just standing, getting aggravated, fighting, and hustling. I got a partner and me that always walk the yard, we always say man what, we took prison the wrong way, we always waiting on lawyers to get something did, and we always talk about Calvin and we always said we should've been in the law library with them guys there. Because you stay in the law library for 30 years sooner or later you going to come up with the key to open the door.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: We became byproducts of the prison. When you become byproducts of prison you study going under. Me and my partner, he's from Lafayette, we always say that. We were young and not thinking, just acting. Thinking lawyers going to take care of this. But they lawyer, he ain't worried about you, he's just getting him money to feed his family. I mean I'm not saying all lawyers, but lawyers I dealt with have.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: If you could go back in time and give that young man some advice, what would you tell him?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: If I could go back in time when you've been in prison for a duration of time you always go back in time in your mind. Something my grandmas always told me, "Stop doing what you're doing". I used to be a seamen too, I had a ship like my dad on Warden and Tchoupitoulas. I used to be a marine too. "Stay on the ship, don't go and get off the ship, stay focused. And nothings worth your freedom, no money in the world's worth your freedom."

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Any advice on how to do time?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Dang. Doing time, no, it's totally hard. Because, when we came from the gate, it had men here, everybody conducted themself in a man matter, it was more respect here. I mean it's the respect is gone in prison, the thing about doing time now stay focused, stay doing something positive, stay trying to find a way out of here.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Even when they deny you in courts, stay filling because you're still in here. Stay on top of what's most important for you. Today you got to go around things, the generations are different with guys in prison.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How is this new generation of young guys?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Out of control. Because the older guys you can tell us something. You can't tell the young cats nothing because they don't want to listen to advice. I mean my advice would be: look man, put the cell phone down, put the mojo down, or the heroin or whatever drugs you on, get in the law library, and stay focused. Stay focused.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So, you said you were really mad when you came in, I can understand that.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Circumstances, how I come to prison. I mean you turn yourself in, the lawyer tells me I'm going to get you out, you go to court, they don't have nobody saying you killed nobody, somebody said you left with him, they come up there you get a life sentence, you like man I always thought you just had somebody point you out and say he the one that did the killing. Yeah, mad, I mean I'm still mad, I just handle it in different ways now. I learned that court did it different.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: But you had already said you had kind of gone down the wrong road anyway. So what lead to you turning your life around once you came to prison? What made you change?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Because I realized I was trying to fit in somewhere that wasn't me. It's like anything else. You never know people until you get in a place with people. And then when you get in an abnormal environment like this you say "Man this not me, I was just a person trying to fit in, this ain't me. I'm not even this dude". I think some dudes breaded for prison, made for prison. I think some prison made for some people.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How long into your 31 years now, how long into that.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So can you something specific.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Prison changed. So when prison changed, you have to change. So, all the madness and the fooling I was doing I said what I'm saying, I got to just stay focused.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: But what lead you to that, why didn't you get to that point earlier? Here's where I'm going with this Ron, sometimes people just make a decision they're going to change their life around because maybe from a mentor or sometimes it's through a spiritual awakening or something, sometimes its real gradual, you just kind of age out.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Now that you saying that, I think I'm more in touch with God than I've ever been; and the greatest part about that because I come up with my mom, which is my grandmother, she went to church every Sunday. I come up in a house with God, but I'm more in touch with God now than I've ever been than when I was 23, 24, 25, 26, and 30. I'm more spiritual now than I ever was. I think God touched me in a lot of ways that I know I'm not a bad person because they got a lot of guys that left here that I did a lot of good things for while they was here.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: They actually come back to see me, actually help me pay lawyers and they actually do things for me right now. My son be like I got you dad. So I put people on the right track. That partner of mine's name is Jones he brothers, he was in reentry up here. I used to just tell him "Man, stay from behind the building, stay focused, you gone get out". He came to see me a few weeks ago and he brother brings him up here he buying a house in New Orleans east. He's well, I wouldn't be where I'm at. So I helped people.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Sure. But what lead you to turn that around?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I feel like if you helped one person you did well.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah I agree. But I'm trying to understand more about 1997.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I stayed locked up for 3 years for a guy. In the 3 years I stayed locked up I stayed in the cell, then when I was in the cell I had altercations with guys. Getting aggravated and fighting in the cell. Then in 1997 when I realized man these dudes ain't is crap. Back away, stay focused, get out. What I'm saying, stop depending on lawyers.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What's your typical day now?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Well, I work in the administration building, where y'all come through at, at the front. I go to work 12 hours a day. I read books, I eat meals all day. I just work and I just stay busy.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: What's your job in the building?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Orderly. Clean up, cook eggs, and fix coffee, whatever needed. Then they got a few young guys. A lot of guys that have been here from New Orleans, so I know they people. When I catch them I try to tell them right from wrong, if they listen it's cool if not I keep going.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah. Are there some organizations that you're part of here at Angola?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: No, but I got a certificate from a lot of organizations that I've been a part of.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, tell me a little bit about that.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Like concept back then with Buck Buck years ago at camp C. I did the thing. I mean, AIDS awareness.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Have you taken advantage of any of the vocational training that Angola has now?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: No.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I know it's hard if you're serving a life sentence to get into those things.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I always feel if I can ever get out of prison and I was in good health. I can always go back on the ship because, I couldn't get my passport to go nowhere until I get my citizenship back, but I can always go back on the ship. I still got my Z card.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I don't want to dwell on the crime, that's not why we're here to talk. But you've been punished for 31 years now.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Right.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: How much punishment is enough?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I always ask myself that. But even now when I look at the Life channel. Here they got different states that people commit crimes, the same type of crimes that we're charged for, convicted for, and they get 25 years. And here we doing 30 years, like Kansas and St Louis when you look at the life channel, they tell you after how much time a person got for killing somebody or whatever.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: And that's what I'm saying, this state is an unmerciful state. I've been here 31 years, they got guys at camp that was here 25 years before I got here. This state is an unforgiving state. That's a good question, when is enough?

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When you look back whenever I explain what we're doing with this project. I think a very fair question that people will say to me is: well wait a minute, what about the victim? They didn't get a second chance, what are you talking about.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I feel like when you say about the victim, I feel like the average person here with a life sentence for killing somebody they can put breath back in the body, but it's the circumstances you say look at the victim. Okay, besides this state and 2 other states, they got the victim in every state you can never give a person they life back. I mean, it's just too much time they give here. You going to keep a man all this time just put him in front of a firing squad and kill him, shoot him, stop him from suffering.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: When you look back on your crime, and the victim's family, was it somebody you knew?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Miguel that I'm arrested for I knew him. He, they not even from this country.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: So this is a difficult question to ask you guys. But we have to talk about it. Even when there's hope that something may change, I'm sure that you've confronted the fact that you may never get out of here. You may die here. How do you cope with that?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I think, like, not just me. I think the thing that's keeping the population going now, like the thing with the 40 year lifers, guys been there 40 years and they just got that. I think that dudes like me with a life sentence with no parole no benefit to die here, I think that keep us going that one day that something change for us. I mean because not just that, that's not a difficult question because if we didn't have hope, you think we can get up and go to work every day. And some days be harder than others.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Do you see guys just kind of give up and accept the fact that they're just not going to get out?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I think the younger guys is more like "I don't give a damn", than the older guys. You got to understand this, a lot of older guys died off, some, half the guys I was here with they not even here no more. When guys were in the law library, they was trying to get guys out of here. You don't see them with the same people in the law library. I don't even think the young guys worried about getting out.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I mean you can die at any age. But I feel like the governor did something new about it since I been confined. That's the hope that keep the older guys like me here hoping this governor do the right thing and change some laws even when they say parole for life, that don't mean you going to make parole, that just mean you can go on the parole board.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, it's not a get out of jail free card.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: So, when you saying like, when death call it's going to call, ne certain age, no rich man no poor man, death going to get you. So I don't, the hope keep us going. That's why I touched the spiritual part of my life cause a guy told me the other day, a good friend of mine that helped me pay lawyers, he said "Man, I can pay any lawyer you want, but when God open the doors for humanity they not going to be able to stop it" That stuck in my mind.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I mean God got you here, you don't have to be here. This is something that 20 years ago when you're career first started you never thought you'd be in Angola doing this. So, what I'm saying, I don't, God said even if it don't work, God still have you on because you got the heart to say that's just too long, 37 years. You can go to camp F and ask guys "How long you been in jail?", "Since '61, '62" That's why I say I'm getting like the spiritual part of things. Because you don't have to come here.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah the oldest guy we talked with was Sammy Robinson.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: And he come from reform school here. They got guys done I met here never even had a woman.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. He was 15.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Yeah, and you asked me a question, a friend of mine, his name, he at camp F, his brother's name Gil I just saw him pass matter of fact. They come here, one of them had 15 years, and one of them had 40 years. They kill a guy here. And when they kill a guy here, they had no hope for getting out. They went and got life in saint from killing a guy here.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: They give him a 40 year life. So now they're on their way out, so you never know. You got to say focused when if something do happen you'll be in the right position for that. Now these guys had no hope, but they bout to go home. Because that ain't man, that's God touching that. I'm just showing you.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: I agree.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: I'm walking the yard in 1980, I said "Bill what's wrong?" He crying, I never saw a grown man cry. He said, "Man you know what the day is? I said "What?" He said "The day of my 40 year I discharge" His brother had 50 he been discharged. That was 1989 and now its 2017. Because of guys like Norris, guys like Calvin, we going to fight, do the right thing. We just ask them to do the right thing. Because I wouldn't even want a man to come out who's not ready for the street.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Right. Angola's definitely changed since you've been here. I mean everybody's talking about that for sure. What, for you, is the worst part of this prison?

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: Worst part of this prison. I mean, my worst thing is just waking up in the morning, just being here. I mean, everything. When you get older your view become, everything really going to get on your nerves when you get older the food going to get on your nerves, the young inmates going to get on your nerves. Not to the point where you going to do anything about or nothing, you just get mad, this what I sold my soul for, this what I'm settling for. I don't know.

transcript.speaker: Marcus
transcript.content: Yeah, it's probably a silly question. I mean the worst thing about being in prison is prison.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: You looking at like, you be here so long, everybody going to die. Your mama going to die if you got a mama, your daddy going to die if you got a daddy, your brothers, sisters, you be here so long. Love is priceless, and when you come to prison, you hurt a lot of people. You send your people somewhere in chains to come and see you.

transcript.speaker: Ron
transcript.content: They not criminals but they got to go before dawn, they got to go in a metal detector, none of my people criminals. They worked they whole life.
